If [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{B} = \{ v_1; v_2; \ldots ; v_ n\}[/mathjaxinline] is a basis of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline], then the coordinatization map [mathjaxinline]C: V \rightarrow \mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline] given by [mathjaxinline]C(w) = [w]_{\mathcal{B}}[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation which is both into and onto.

div.p: In the video, we proved that [mathjaxinline]C[/mathjaxinline] is into and onto, but we did not show that [mathjaxinline]C[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation. We do that here.
To show that [mathjaxinline]C[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation, we must show that [mathjaxinline]C[/mathjaxinline] respects vector addition and scalar multiplication.

If [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{B} = \{ v_1; v_2; \ldots ; v_ n\}[/mathjaxinline] is a basis of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]k>n[/mathjaxinline], then any list of [mathjaxinline]k[/mathjaxinline] vectors in [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] must be linearly dependent.
